segments.text: Dr. Richardson?
You came well, sir.
Who are you?
Okay.
My name is Herbert H. Richardson.
Born in Lynn, Massachusetts, in 1930, September 24, 1930.
Shortly after I was born,
family moved to Maine to a small town called Bridgeton.
Bridgeton.
Bridgeton.
About, at that time, 3,000 people.
Where is Bridgeton?
Population.
Bridgeton is approximately 40 miles north of Portland.
Okay.
It's near the Sebago Lake region.
We spent a week or two there.
I really enjoyed it.
The people were nice.
It's very pretty up there in Paul.
My father started out as a blacksmith and a mechanic, and then later on when automobiles began to come in and
and so on, he got into the machine trades.
Actually lived in the small town of Bridgeton early in his career.
Moved to Massachusetts, where he worked in the Navy Yard on submarines and other precision devices used during the war.
and continued in that kind of work until after I was born, and that was during the Depression.
There was not a very good situation down there, so that led him to move with the family back to Maine, where he started a small business doing welding and blacksmith work and machine work.
Eventually developed that into a very thriving business
designing and building snow plows.
It was a good market for snow plows.
Motorized on a tractor type device or just the plow itself?
Mounted on a truck.
Developed one of the first hydraulic systems for positioning the plow and the wings that it used to set back snow banks at the side of the road.
Did he patent those?
He had some patents on hydraulic systems.
So anyways, I grew up, he wanted me to be an engineer and wanted me to take over the business.
So by the time I was eight years old, I was working in the business operating machine tools.
I had to have a bench to stand on so I could reach the controls.
I learned welding, machining, all those kinds of things.
I did work in the business part-time all the way through high school.
During the time that my father lived in Massachusetts, he worked in a
in a machine shop called Olmsted and Flint Company, which is located in Cambridge, adjacent to the MIT campus.
And he got acquainted with a large number of MIT students.
They used to come over and watch him work and shop.
And so he developed an aspiration for me to go to MIT.
and become an engineer.
Well, the high school that I went to had a total of about 200 students.
And no one from that school had ever gone out of state to college.
And most did not go to college in state.
At any rate, I ended up deciding I did not want to be an engineer.
but wanted to go into physics.
And so I applied and was accepted to Colby College, a very high quality liberal arts school.
Went there against the advice of the high school principal, who told me that I probably wouldn't make it there and should go to the University of Maine.
So I went to Colby and had kind of a
kind of a hard time because my preparation in high school wasn't very good.
But I ended the first semester with a perfect record and found out that physics wasn't quite what I wanted to do and that maybe the old man was right.
And so I went down to Cambridge and applied to MIT.
At the end of the year, I had a perfect day record at Colby, so there was no question about being admitted.
And that's how I started my MIT career.
When year is that, roughly?
It was 1948 was when I started at Colby and at 49.
And I really liked it there at the Institute.
I did major in mechanical engineering.
Mechanical engineering was the next question.
What did you think you would be doing as a mechanical engineer?
Railroad work at that time?
No, designing machinery, essentially.
But as I went through the program, my interests changed.
And I became, in my junior and senior year, very interested in the emerging area of automatic control.
And so I was in what they called the Honors Program, which was a five-year program where you could do one thesis and get two degrees.
I was offered an opportunity to work in one of the wartime laboratories, the Dynamic Analysis and Control Laboratory.
That was at MIT.
At MIT.
It was, at the time, doing work on guided missiles.
And I joined a group that was developing the electro-hydraulic controls for the Meteor missile, which was the first.
autonomous guided missile.
There's another one thing that I just finished doing.
I was writing a history of Johnson Space Center.
Oh, really?
Yeah, that was really fascinating.
I know what you're talking about a little bit.
Well, this facility had an analog computer that was used for trajectory analysis.
It filled a whole floor in one of the buildings
That kind of computer will sit on our desks today.
Yeah, I remember incidentally seeing the computer at Cape Canaveral before NASA was established, I guess.
I had a friend who worked down there, and there were four buildings, I believe, of computers, and they were shooting that redstone off.
And they had these paper tapes.
And my friend's job was to sit there and read the tape and find out when a
The vacuum tube, I guess they were, burned out.
He was an engineer reading the paper, but that was an incredible array of stuff.
Well, anyway, so I worked in that lab, and I was also in ROTC, so I had a military commitment.
I completed my master's degree, and I was planning to go on active duty
In the meantime, I had gotten married, and I found out we were going to have a child.
So I decided maybe that wasn't a good idea.
So in order to avoid going on active duty at that point in time, I talked to my supervisor, and he said, why don't you take the doctoral exams?
And so I did, and it came out real well.
So they offered me a graduate assistantship,
I stayed on and completed a doctoral degree, finishing in 1958.
Did you continue working on that dynamics analysis plan?
Yeah.
And then for a while, for about a year, actually it was prior to receiving my doctorate, I was offered a teaching position and taught
in the control and design area for a year while I was still a graduate student.
I was a graduate instructor.
Following that, I went on.
You liked to teach.
Yeah, yeah.
I went on active duty, and I was stationed eventually at Aberdeen Proving Grounds, where I worked on the effects of nuclear weapons
developed some instrumentation and equipment.
Came back after that, was offered a faculty position at MIT in mechanical engineering.
So what year is that, roughly, do you remember?
That was in 59.
And then I just kind of went through the standard up through the ranks type of process.
That was a time when universities were trying to get out of the military R&D business, and the laboratory that I had been associated with was essentially dismantled.
And I changed my emphasis area from missiles and that sort of thing to transportation and industrial fluid power control.
was a participant in the studies that were done by the then Commerce Department, which led to the formation of the US Department of Transportation.
Continued working for them in research areas like high speed ground transportation, magnetically.
So you stayed primarily in research.
You hadn't gotten into administration too much.
No, I wasn't in administration.
Then there was an opportunity to go to the Department of Transportation to work for the then Secretary John Volpe as the first chief scientist in the department.
So I moved to Washington and did that for two years.
Learned a lot about politics and how to get things done.
in the political environment, worked all across the agencies of the department.
And your title was what?
Chief scientist.
And I got a couple of university programs going that continued for more than a decade afterwards, funding
generic type research at universities.
Did you have any encounters along the way with Texas A&M at that time?
Yes.
In fact, that comes back to the question you asked me, how did I know about Texas A&M.
When I was doing the work to put together this university program, I went all around the country to the leading institutes in
The Texas Transportation Institute, which was headed by Jack Keese at that time, was clearly one of the stronger university-based institutes of its kind, but with a very special character.
It was very much oriented toward highway infrastructure, construction, highway design, safety.
So it was narrow in the sense that it was just a
a small piece of one mode of transportation.
And it was very, very applied.
There was essentially no basic research going on.
But yet it was very notable.
And that was the first time I had ever come to the A&M campus.
So that was in 1971, roughly.
I knew Jack Keyes and Cubby Manning about the time.
They were in Little League with me.
We were coaching Little League or something.
You knew who those people were.
So anyway, coming back to the MIT situation, after DOT, I was there two years.
And then I came back to MIT with a lot of ideas on what MIT should be doing in transportation.
worked on the establishment of the Center for Transportation Studies at MIT.
And then a year later was asked to become head of the ME department.
So I took that over.
It was kind of a low spot in the history of the department, because the enrollment was way down.
They were talking about maybe changing their name to something else.
And there had been a significant reduction in the size of the faculty.
So things were kind of at a low.
And I guess I was lucky or something, but I was able to build the department back up and generate a lot of new programs.
I have some outstanding faculty.
I was in that job for eight years.
And by the time I had left, I had hired almost half of the faculty members on my watch.
It was partly due to some early retirements, making open positions, and partly due to the fact the department grew.
Very, very.
Was MIT holding their enrollment pretty stable during that time?
The overall enrollment, yeah.
But there were a lot of shifts.
So anyway, I did that for eight years.
Then I was asked to come into the dean's office as associate dean, which I did.
After I'd been in that position for a year, year and a half, was when I was first approached by Texas A&M.
I guess I didn't take it very seriously, but one thing, there were almost no nationally visible faculty members.
When I went over the list of faculty that was
I think only a couple of faculty members I'd ever heard of.
And so it was not a very visible college.
But finally, the people here were very persistent.
And finally, I did.
Who are you dealing with, primarily?
Well, it was Arthur Hanson, who was the chancellor at that time, Frank Vandiver.
Gordon Eaton was the provost.
And Jack Flipsey, who was president of the Research Foundation, was very instrumental in convincing me.
Is that right?
He is one of the people that I did know.
So I finally did come down, and I found it was a pretty intriguing situation.
back and forth quite a bit.
But in the end, as I thought about it, I thought, well, I can stay at MIT.
I've got a real great position here.
I'm doing well.
And I can make an incremental difference.
But if I came to a place like A&M with a resolve to say I had to really be something, I could make a major difference.
And that was why I came and had a little problem with my spouse.
because she didn't even want to come down and look.
Oh, is that right?
Yeah, she said, Texas, that's tumbleweed and snakes.
Oh, that's a universal thing.
Anything to do with that.
Finally, she said, okay, well, I'll go down, but if I see one snake, just forget it.
I hope you call ahead and clear those things out, because they are here.
But she came down, and she...
She really took a shine to the place.
They didn't see his name.
Found out there were, in fact, trees and grass.
They were always amazed.
And then there was a good opportunity for her in veterinary medicine.
So she, at the time, had a couple of master's degrees and was going to go on.
If we'd stayed there, she would have gone on at Harvard to get a doctorate.
So we came down.
Oh, I had not realized you were .
So the first thing I did was I recruited Jack Flipsey to come over and help me, which turned out to be a very good move.
And then kept Skip Fletcher on as associate dean.
He knew where all the bodies were buried,
and who'd done what to whom.
So as you know, we integrated the agencies in with the College of Engineering.
And I was dean and I was vice chancellor with the agencies reporting to me.
There was a very destructive relationship at that time between the engineering experiment station and the College of Engineering.
And to fix that, I had myself appointed.
I appointed myself as director of the experiment station.
And we went about integrating the faculty.
We did away.
There was a lot of duplication of centers.
There'd be a center in TEAS, and there'd be another activity in the college.
And they were fighting each other over the budget.
We closed a number of those centers.
And others, like the computer center that was in Tees, we gave to computer science.
It was kind of a stressful time.
Yeah, I can imagine.
What did you see as your, was it more of an administrative, structural problem or mission that you felt you had here?
Or what was your total sense of the problem?
motive or mission when you arrived?

What was the mission was to develop the engineering program, the college and three agencies, into a first-rate, high-quality, nationally visible program that would attract top-quality students, produce top-quality graduates,
to strengthen the graduate programs in particular, to increase the level of sponsored research, and to generally develop the program.
So the first step was basically this structural integration of the various components that would form the College of Engineering.
Well, form the engineering program.
And what it did, essentially, it created a situation where the faculty
Instead of having two bosses who were fighting with each other, we had one boss, and that was their department head.
The department head was the department head in the college, but the same person was the division head for research and teas.
And then we set up some incentives so that the indirect cost from research programs
was used to feed back and further strengthen the departments and the programs.
And that worked tremendously well.
And most of those costs been retained in the what?
In the college or in the extension?
In the previous situation, the director of the experiment station had all those monies
And used them to lodge yes and to reward friends rather than performers.
So this is just a direct plow back, in effect, to the department, depending on the volume of activity generated by that department.
That's right.
It's what in control we call a positive feedback loop.
The other thing that we did was we established
clear set of criteria for promotion, tenure, and appointment, and made sure that all the faculty knew about it.
We strengthened the review process, the tenure process.
And the other thing that I did when I first came here was establish a
a development activity, fundraising activity.
Who headed that?
Well, Kyle Jedeke is the person.
He's still there.
He's a chemical engineer, has an MBA.
And I made a deal with the Development Foundation where we pay half the salary and they pay half the salary.
But I got to hire the individual.
And he physically located an engineering.
And that worked very well.
Raised a lot of money.
A lot of chairs and a lot of professorships.
Were you, I suppose there were a lot of new recruiting going on.
Oh, yes.
Soon.
There was.
Did you sort of personally participate in a lot of that?
Oh, yes.
I know at one level you had.
What about your relation as the deans, let's say, with the other structures and deans in the university?
I think it was pretty good.
We established these divisions in any other college that wanted it so they could participate.
I think the one that gets the prize for utilizing that best is liberal arts.
Dan Fallon was just...
When he came here, there was hardly 25 cents in research money.
And he very astutely used the T's money to leverage the research activity of liberal arts.
In fact, even the concept of his paid, funded research was not very well known in the college of liberal arts.
So that's kind of the situation, I guess.
How about support from the administration, president, and so forth?
Well, we had, the place had, at least had a little money left, and they did make a commitment of around $13 million in development money over a period of about five years.
And, yeah, I've always had good
relationships with the administration.
Every now and then there's a problem that usually has to do with money, but overall I think the college had good relations with the other colleges and with the administration.
Were there any new directions you were trying to

Well, one thing I could tell you by way of impressions when I first came on the job, I got all the department heads together and tried to tell them a little bit about my style and I expected initiative from them.
It was a real quiet meeting.
Nobody wanted to say anything.
And so finally I said, well, what do you folks want to do?
What are your ideas?
And one of them finally piped up and said, well, Dr. Richardson, just tell us what you want us to do.
We'll do it.
That was the Aggie way.
That's right.
I was just flabbergasted.
Because where I come from, it's all prima donnas.
There were some very strong walls between departments.
There were departments that would say to a faculty member, I don't want you working on this project with, like if you're in mechanical, I don't want you working on a project in civil engineering.
Your job is to be working here in this department.
I remember Dr. Calhoun used to talk about the walls of this university.
That took quite a while.
It essentially took a new set of department heads, many of them brought in from outside, to change that.
I think today there's a pretty permeable.
You would have done a lot, because my perception is that the College of Engineering is the strongest
College of the University.
And it was the oldest, you might say, most deeply established and entrenched.
And there hadn't, in fact, been a lot of inbred development here.
And so I'm sure it was a pretty static world that you would imagine.
What about the, I guess let's move on to the chancellorship and so forth.
What's happening in terms of the University?
period of temporary insanity there where I decided that I'd be receptive to taking on this job.
The A&M system until fairly recent years has not been what I would call a system.
In the first place, for many years, as you know,
It was really dominated by Texas A&M University.
And so you had this situation where sometimes the chancellor would be the president, or the president would be the chancellor.
And a lot of conflict as to who was running things.
And strong personalities who felt strongly that they should be running it instead of having a kind of a...
I remember I was so impressed when Tom Harrington said, you know what we really should have done long ago is move the systems headquarters to Dallas.
That's strange coming from an Aggie.
But he had a point, I think, and the point was that this conflict might have been better alleviated.
Excuse me.
In 1989, when we were given these four new institutions.
Which were?
Okay, which were Laredo State University in Laredo, Texas A&I University in Kingsville, Corpus Christi State University, Corpus Christi, and West Texas State University in Canyon.
and Amarillo.
Laredo and Corpus Christi were and still are upper division.
They did not have freshman sophomores.
Laredo still does not have its own campus.
Its base is leased from Laredo Junior College.
And West Texas, of course, was in difficulty.
Their enrollment was down.
Excuse me, was this acquisition, would you say, at least in part at the initiative of the A&M Regents, or what was the attitude there?
But I know there were conflicts.
I would say it was more a passive act.
Let me answer it this way.
It was not a situation where the A&M system had an overall long-range strategy.
and saw these institutions as important components that, if they could be acquired, would help to promote that long-term strategy.
There was no long-term strategy for the system.
In fact, what the system mostly did was, what we call, ensure fiduciary integrity.
manage the books, carry out audit functions, invest money for the common good, manage our share of the permanent university fund and the AUF.
And together with the regents, hire and fire presidents and agency directors.
Beginning...

really with Perry Atkinson's administration, that there began to be some long-range thinking about what the A&M system should be and what its mission should be in the state and what areas should it try to emphasize and de-emphasize.
And I think Perry Atkinson had
some very good long-range visions as to what the system might become in the future.
I think felt very strongly that the emphasis should really be in engineering and agriculture because that's the place where the system has a good deal of strength.
Of course, those universities that came into the system
at that time did not add a lot to those strengths, even though there was some agriculture programs.
A&I has a respectable engineering program.
You wouldn't say that it had much effect on the overall activity.
So there was a lot of soul-searching, I think, out of the board during the time Perry was chancellor.

A study was done, I guess about four years ago, was the year before Perry announced he was going to step down, by McKenzie and Company, where they looked at some indicators for higher education throughout Texas and compared

compared those indicators with what was going on nationally and looked at various attributes of particularly the universities that were in the system at that time, eight of them, and tried to characterize them.
Were they high engineering, high agriculture, low engineering, low agriculture, no engineering, no agriculture?
and what the quality was as indicated by the admissions SAT scores of entering students, kind of came to the conclusion that a number of these universities didn't really fit our system.
And I think there was some sentiment at that time that the study was done in part to defend the system against other institutions being given to us.
So the idea was try to come up with some rationale so that if some institution, Sol Ross or whatever, decides they want to join, you can say, yeah, that makes sense, ignore it.
No, it doesn't.
Well, that study was finished.
And then Perry announced he was going
and stepped down.
So everything was kind of put on hold pending the arrival of the new chancellor.
As part of that process, though, there had been established a committee, a regent committee on strategic planning and long-range goals and strategic planning headed by Raul Fernandez.
So the mechanism was in place.
And when Bill Mobley was here with Perry, he had initiated a comprehensive strategic planning process for the whole system.
And there had been one iteration.
So that was in place.
When I came over here, one of the first questions that I tried to deal with is just that.
What is the A&M system anyway?
What do we want it to be?
What's its mission in the state as compared with other systems?
Particularly, how is it different from the UT system in terms of the missions and goals?
And we had a whole series of meetings with the Regents Planning Committee,
and with our CEOs, agency directors, and presidents on that issue.
The outcome of that was a short statement of what the A&M system is, besides being a collection of 15 institutions.
Do you have that somewhere?
Yes, I do.
We also have a vision statement that
It expresses what some of our values are, things like being a premier source of education, research, and new technology in the state.
One question that I guess needs to be asked somewhere along here is, are you cooperating at this point
With University of Texas, is there any collusion in the sense of joint planning and development?
I wouldn't say there was joint planning, particularly.
We try to collaborate pretty closely in the legislative session.
Which is really relevant to new development, too.
It is.
But Cunningham and I at Shilkin Lawless have been kind of a
coalition of the big dogs, if you will.
And we've met frequently and coordinated different kinds of activities.
And that collaboration developed in part because of, whatever they were, the financial tensions on the systems and higher education generally in Texas.
Because I know every school wanted to re-enact itself to something to get a portion of the available funds, et cetera, et cetera.
And we have some collaborative research programs between UT and A&M.
In engineering, for instance, the Offshore Technology Center, NTS, the Southwestern University Transportation Research Center, NTTI.
It's a collaboration between A&M and UT Austin.
And there are others.
There's a space grant consortium.
There's always a certain amount of ego that gets into those things, that gets in the way.
Let me ask this.
How have the regents reacted to this collaboration?
Very positive.
I guess I don't want to keep you too much longer, Dr. Richardson.
What have been your greatest, you might say, difficulties, problems, or issues as chancellor of the system?
And where do you see the system heading?
Of course, a uniform difficult challenge in these times is the financial one.
So dealing with the legislature in particular, the state legislature, and trying to be sure that we get our share of the funding, that is one of the most difficult challenges.
What about you?
I think in terms of new directions, I see my job, a lot of my job is to encourage collaboration and synergy among these 15 institutions that we have.
So that each president or CEO has a sense of dual citizenship.
One, of course, is as the leader in their particular unit, whether it's Texas A&M University or it's the Ag Extension Service, but also to feel a sense of citizenship in the system as a whole.
So that while they need to look inward and look to the support of their units and the growth and development of their units, they also have to look upward and outward
with a responsibility to help the system as a whole be more and do more than the collection of the individual parts can.
We're in a very enviable position in a lot of ways because of the presence of these statewide research and service agencies in engineering and agriculture.
They provide, in a lot of ways, the web
or the network that encourages institutions to work together.
Yeah, that's in the Extension Experiment Station tradition, I guess.
Yes.
So it's really .
I think that one issue for the future is the relationship of the system to industry.
particularly Texas industry, but not limited to that.
In engineering, the way things have developed, there are many, many very strong collaborative relationships now.
Programs where there will be a large number of small companies that come together with people from faculty and students, or
major industries, like the major oil company.
Every major oil company supports the Offshore Technology Center.
I know I was always struck by the interaction between the academia side of things and the NASA side of things.
It was just an open door going back and forth.
Yeah.
These kinds of relationships don't exist so much, though,
other areas like some aspects at least of the marine area and agriculture in particular.
And so one of my goals and one of the goals that I've asked Ed Hila to adopt in his new position as the leader of agriculture in the system is to begin to foster and develop
similar kind of relationships with industries that have an interest in agriculture and the life sciences.

And the first example of that is the Center for Vegetable and Crop Improvement headed by Leonard Pike, which now has an industry consortium that's working with which is sort of a vertically integrated
The Saudi each has shippers and suppliers and growers and food processors and what not.
